prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person (the author) is in the wrong for not keeping her husband undisturbed while he works from home. The situation is that the husband set up his office in the bedroom instead of the basement despite the wife's suggestion. His job involves a lot of conference calls, and when he's in the bedroom, the wife can't do basic things like shower, do chores, or nap because the kids can't disturb him. She's handling most of the housework and childcare, and she told him she can't guarantee silence if he stays in the bedroom. He thinks she's the problem, but she thinks he should have chosen the basement.

First, I need to assess if the author is in the wrong. The key points here are about mutual respect and shared responsibilities in a home. The husband chose the bedroom over the basement, which the wife offered as a more suitable location for his work setup. By choosing a space that's also shared (the bedroom), he's impacting her ability to use that space and manage household duties. The wife is asking him to adjust, which seems reasonable. The husband's choice leads to her being unable to perform her tasks. 

Is the wife obligated to keep him undisturbed even if his choice of workspace creates conflict? The husband's job requires a quiet environment, but the wife's responsibilities as a parent and homemaker are also significant. The fact that the basement is available and would minimize disruption suggests that the husband's choice is the root cause. The wife is essentially caught between her own work and household duties and the need to accommodate his work setup. 

So, the author is not in the wrong because the husband made a choice that affects her ability to function. She's trying to communicate her needs and suggest a better alternative. The husband's refusal to move could be seen as not considering her workload. Therefore, the answer should be B (No).
